title: God Bless Mr. Devil
features: After long hours of hard work and sleepless nights, Satan has the world by the tail and things are looking good. Until an eight-year-old girl comes up with the idea that praying for the Devils salvation will rid the world of evil.

Of course, everything goes to hell from there. While the Devil attempts to shut this little brat kid up, her sincere compassion for his welfare begins to take its toll on his emotions. In the end, Satan faces a serious problem: Lose everything he has ever worked for, or bring down the child he now loves. The solution? There is only one; Hell must survive.
description: "I just want to know when the sequel is coming out." --
"I simply could not put it down." --
"The best book I have ever read." --

Every now and then, the book that every publisher dreams about, the one that propels readers into a striking visual experience and leaves them with an unforgettable sense of joy in their lives comes along.

God Bless Mr. Devil, a novel by Andrew Davis, is such a book. Set in Atlanta, GA during December, this wonderful story hurls the reader through its snowy, blizzard landscape with the power and velocity of a runaway locomotive, to its memorable happy ending on Christmas Day. We are so fortunate to present this gripping piece of feel-good work to the reading public. Please visit the Web site for this book at: godblessmrdevil.com

As is true with most of the great ideas a writer comes across, this one just spoke to me. I heard someone ask another person "Why doesn't anyone pray for the Devil? God Bless Mr. Devil is the result of that encounter. Please visit the Web site at: godblessmrdevil.com, and ENJOY!

Andrew Jefferson Davis was born in Clarksville, TN. He graduated from Montgomery Central High School in Clarksville, he's a Veteran of the United States Marine Corps, and he's a Black Belt in Shotokan Karate. He was a Political Science major at Austin Peay State University in Clarksville and holds a BFA in theatrical lighting from the North Carolina School of the Arts. He's a former lighting director with The Nashville Network, and he's been writing fiction since 1986. God Bless Mr. Devil is his second novel.
